Knuckles the Echidna, fictional Sonic the Hedgehog video game character

Brass knuckles - Brass knuckles, also sometimes called knuckles, knucks, brass knucks, or knuckledusters, are weapons used in hand-to-hand combat.
knuckle joint (mechanical), used to connect the two rods which are under the tensile load
knuckle definition: the rounded prominence formed by the ends of the two adjacent bones at a joint —used especially of those at the joints of the fingers.
Knuckle - The knuckles are the joints of the fingers and toes, which are brought into prominence when the hand is clenched and a fist is made.

wiki.text:
The 'knuckles' are the joints of the fingers which are brought into prominence
when the hand is clenched and a fist is made. The word is cognate to similar
words in other Germanic languages, such as the Dutch "Knokkel" (knuckle) or
German "Knöchel" (ankle), i.e., Knöchlein, the diminutive of the German word for
bone (Knochen). Anatomically, it is said that the knuckles consist of the
metacarpophalangeal<ref name="UTMntn">Utah Mountain Biking;
[http://www.utahmountainbiking.com/firstaid/thumbspr.htm Thumb Sprain]; First as
metacarpo.</ref> and interphalangeal joints of the finger. The knuckles at the
base of the fingers may be referred to as the 1st<ref name="UTMntn"/> or major
knuckles while the knuckles at the midfinger are known as the
2nd<ref>[http://www.polykarbon.com/tutorials/hands/hands.htm Second knuckle as
thumb's interphalangeal, "anchor knuckle" as metacarpophalangeal]</ref> and 3rd,
or minor, knuckles. However, the ordinal terms are used inconsistently, and can
be found referring to any of the
knuckles.<ref>[http://www.ahntaichi.com/eyemassage.html First knuckle as thumb's
interphalangeal]</ref><ref>[http://www.tutorials.com/08/0876/08761.asp First
knuckle as distal interphalangeal]</ref>

The physical mechanism behind the popping or cracking sound heard when cracking
joints such as knuckles is still uncertain, although it is widely believed to be
caused by synovial fluid filling the vacuum left by the joint's
displacement.<ref>John Hopkins Arthritis Center, [http://www.hopkins-arthritis.org/arthritis-news/2007/knuckle-cracking-and-
arthritis.html Knuckle Cracking and Arthritis]</ref><ref></ref>
wiki.title: Knuckle
